answer_html: with \(a \not= 0\) is an eigenvector of A with eigenvalue 3.
answer_latex: with $a \not= 0$ is an eigenvector of \emph{A} with eigenvalue 3.
hints_html:
To calculate the eigenvectors v for the eigenvalue 3, find the solution of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (A- 3I)v = 0\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
To calculate the eigenvectors ''v'' for the eigenvalue 3, find the solution of 

:<math>\displaystyle (A- 3I)v = 0 </math>
question: B 04 (a)
sols_html:
Proceeding as usual, we look for non-zero solutions to

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = (A-3I)v = \begin{bmatrix} -10 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & -7 \end{bmatrix}v\end{aligned}\]

The free variable is v2, while there is a system of two equations and two unknowns for v1 and v3. The (simplest and only) solution to this smaller system is v1 = 0 = v3. Hence, any vector of the form

\[\begin{aligned} v = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ a \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

with \(a \not= 0\) is an eigenvector of A with eigenvalue 3.
sols_raw:
Proceeding as usual, we look for non-zero solutions to

:<math>
0 = (A-3I)v = \begin{bmatrix}
-10 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & -7
\end{bmatrix}v
</math>

The free variable is ''v<sub>2</sub>'', while there is a system of two equations and two unknowns for ''v<sub>1</sub>'' and ''v<sub>3</sub>''. The (simplest and only) solution to this smaller system is ''v<sub>1</sub> = 0 = v<sub>3</sub>''. Hence, any vector of the form

:<math>
v = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ a \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

with <math> a \not= 0 </math> is an eigenvector of ''A'' with eigenvalue 3.
statement_html:
Let A be the \(3 \times 3\) matrix given by

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -7 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 &-4 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

It is known that \(\lambda_{1} = 3\) is an eigenvalue of A.

Find an eigenvector associated with the eigenvalue \(\lambda_{1} = 3\).
statement_raw:
Let ''A'' be the <math> 3 \times 3 </math> matrix given by

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-7 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
-2 & 0 &-4
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

It is known that <math> \lambda_{1} = 3</math> is an eigenvalue of ''A''.

Find an eigenvector associated with the eigenvalue <math>\lambda_{1} = 3 </math>.
